' .n .. Ail- - *MMCONCLUSIONS of.a.Meeting-of the War Cabinet held atWDownmg Street,S.W.1, on Sunday, November 5, 1939^ at 12 noon.., Present:'The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.Admiral of the Fleet the Right Hon.Lord Chatfield,: Minister for Co-ordination of Defence.The following were also present:Admiral of the Fleet Sir dudley pound, First Sea Lord and Chief ofNaval Staff. ' : ; -Air Vice-Marshal R. E. C. Peirse,Deputy Chief of the Air Staff.Major-General H. R. S. Ma^sy,Deputy Chief of the ImperialGeneral Staff.Secretariat.Sir Rupert Howorth.Lieutemamt-Oolomei E. I. C. Jacob. WAR CABINET 71 (89).No. Subject.1 Air Operations ... ......2 Naval Operations ....... ...3 Military Operations ... ...4 Germany- ...... ........Internal condition.5 Italy ... ... ...... ... ..The recent changes in party and military posts.6 The City of Flint ... ... ... W.M. 71 (89).
? (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 70th Conclusions, Minute 1.)
1. The Deputy Chief of the Air Staff said that there was nothing of interest to report.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Naval Operations. (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 70th Conclusions, Minute 2.)
2. The First Sea Lord said that there had been further cases of merchant ships which had struck mines through disregarding the routeing instructions which had been given them. A Danish, a Norwegian and a Greek ship had all been sunk in this manner off the East coast.
A merchant ship, on its way from Scandinavia to Cardiff, had been attacked by a submarine, but had escaped.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Military Operations. (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 70th Conclusions, Minute 4.)
3. The Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that one more German Division had been identified in the Saar area, which brought the total of German Divisions up to 133. There were reports of a concentration of 10,000 troops, including cavalry, at Emmerich, near the Dutch border, but the General Staff did not attach much significance to this.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
Germany. Internal condition. (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 68th Conclusions, Minute 5.)
4. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs read to the War Cabinet telegram No. 89, dated the 4th November, from Mr. Osborne, His Majesty's Minister to the Holy See, reporting that a German doctor, who had recently been in Italy for consultation, had told a friend of Mr. Osborne (an expatriate German Jew) that very considerable numbers of young German troops had had to be sent back from the Front for reasons of health. Intensive physical training, to which they had been subjected, combined with lack of nourishment and rest, had, while developing their bodies, left them with enfeebled stamina and powers of resistance. A great many had had to be replaced by older men, while they had returned to police and other duties on the Home Front, where they were a nuisance and menace to the population.
The War Cabinet took note of this information.
Italy. The recent changes in party and military posts. (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 67th Conclusions, Minute 12.)
5. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that he had received several reports on the recent ministerial and military changes in Italy, which supported the views which we had already formed as to the political implications of these changes.
The Foreign Secretary read to the War Cabinet extracts from a letter, dated the lst November, from Sir Noel Charles, British Chargé d'Affaires in Rome. It was stated in this letter that these changes had come as a surprise to everyone in Rome and it was known for a fact that most of the victims themselves had only heard of their fate at about 8 A.M. on the morning of the 31st October. The German Ambassador in Rome had been recalled on the 30th October for the purposes of consultation and, in reply to a suggestion by M. François-Poncet that Herr von Mackensen had probably been in a position to inform Herr Hitler of these changes, Count Ciano had stated that the German Ambassador had not been told anything The " City o2 6. The Secretary of State for Foreign A fairs read to the WarFlint." " Cabinet telegram No. 829 from Paris, of the 4th November, in which(Previous Mr. Campbell stated that the United States Ambassador in ParisReference: had informed a member of the Staff of the British Embassy that.M. (39) 70th Mr. Roosevelt was furious about the City of Flint/and had askedConclusions, Mr. Bullitt for suggestions in the way of retaliation on the Soviets.Minute 3.) So far Mr. Bullitt had only been able to suggest (i)' that al Sbvietships in American ports should be detaineda for- inspection! -the inspection could be spun but for weeks, at the end of which theSoviet Authorities might be told that the engines were out of order;(ii) that all visas for the United States for Soviet citizens shouldbe suspended. Mr. Bullitt would welcome any other suggestions.The Prime Minister said that he could only account foj? thestate of quiescence into which Germany seemed to have relapsed bythe supposition that Hitler could not make up his mind what wasthe next step to take.The Minister for Co-ordination of Defence pointed out thatrecently the weather had been against any German air attack onthis country on a large scale.The Deputy Chief of the Air, Staffagreed that this was so asregards the last two or three weeks.The War Cabinettooknote* ofthese asked^ementshRichmond Terrace, S.W.1,.November 5; 1939.
